title: How have alcohol-related deaths changed?
analysis_commentary:
The alcohol-related death rate varies across the UK and is considerably higher in Scotland than the other four constituent countries. In men, there has been a generally increasing trend in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. Scotland saw a peak in alcohol-related death rates in men in 2003 at 48 per 100,000 population. The Institute for Alcohol Studies reported that at that time the Scottish Executive launched plans for action on alcohol problems, which may have contributed to the downward trajectory in alcohol-related deaths in the subsequent decade. In 2012, however, rates began to increase again, despite the release in 2009 of a framework for action Changing Scotlandâ€™s Relationship with Alcohol

As of 2015, Scotland had the highest alcohol-related death rates in both males and females (30 deaths per 100,000 for men and 13.8 per 100,000 for females) whilst England had the lowest (17.8 deaths per 100, 000 for men and 9 deaths per 100,000 for females).

Updated June 2017.
data_source: Office for National Statistics, alcohol-related Deaths
